elements.content: We report the introduction of π-interaction sites into a series of chemically robust metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), MOF-526, -527, and -528, with progressively increased pore size, 1.9–3.7 nm, and the inclusion and release of large organic molecules in water. The mesopores in these MOFs lead to fast adsorption kinetics, whereas the π-interaction between isolated porphyrin units in the MOF backbone and polycyclic structure of the organic guests provides excellent reversibility. Specifically, seven large organic dyes were quantitatively captured by the porphyrin units of these MOFs in a 2:1 molar ratio, exhibiting unprecedented kinetics for MOFs [e.g., 4.54 × 105 L/mol for rhodamine B] at an extremely low concentration (10 ppm) in water. Rotational-echo double-resonance NMR experiments revealed that the distance between the guest molecules and porphyrin units in MOFs was in the range from 3.24 to 3.37 Å, confirming the specific π-interaction. Repetitive and reversible dynamics was achieved in these MOFs for 10 complete inclusion–release cycles without any decay in performance, which is ideally suited for the removal and recycle of large polycyclic organic molecules from water. The performance of MOF-526 rivals that of state-of-the-art carbon and polymers.
elements.clean_text: We report the introduction of π-interaction sites into a series of chemically robust metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), MOF-526, -527, and -528, with progressively increased pore size, 1.9-3.7 nm, and the inclusion and release of large organic molecules in water. The mesopores in these MOFs lead to fast adsorption kinetics, whereas the π-interaction between isolated porphyrin units in the MOF backbone and polycyclic structure of the organic guests provides excellent reversibility. Specifically, seven large organic dyes were quantitatively captured by the porphyrin units of these MOFs in a 2:1 molar ratio, exhibiting unprecedented kinetics for MOFs [e.g., 4.54 × 105 L/mol for rhodamine B] at an extremely low concentration (10 ppm) in water. Rotational-echo double-resonance NMR experiments revealed that the distance between the guest molecules and porphyrin units in MOFs was in the range from 3.24 to 3.37 Å, confirming the specific π-interaction. Repetitive and reversible dynamics was achieved in these MOFs for 10 complete inclusion-release cycles without any decay in performance, which is ideally suited for the removal and recycle of large polycyclic organic molecules from water. The performance of MOF-526 rivals that of state-of-the-art carbon and polymers.

elements.content: π-Interaction, widely existent in biosystems, plays a critical role in their reversible and repetitive operations in aqueous media. Such dynamics are highly desirable in artificial materials for applications including catalysis, molecular separation, sensing, and drug delivery. One critical challenge for the introduction of π-interaction sites into solid-state materials is the interference between these sites at adjacent positions, which limits the access of guest molecules. Theoretically, this should be achievable in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), where the organic linkers are well separated. Extensive efforts were made toward this direction; however, repetitive and reversible dynamics are yet to be demonstrated owing to either the limited pore space in MOFs or the lack of chemical stability in water. Here, we report the repetitive and reversible dynamics in MOFs by fixing π-interaction sites in the backbone instead of protruding into the pores, and thus sufficient pore space was generated for the access of large organic guests, obviating intermolecular interference (B). Specifically, a series of mesoporous MOFs, MOF-526, -527, and -528, with progressively increased pore sizes from 1.9 to 3.7 nm, were constructed by three organic linkers with copper coordinating porphyrin units in the center as the π-interaction sites: [tetrakis­(4-carboxybiphenyl)­porphyrinato]­Cu, [tetrakis­(4-carboxytriphenyl)­porphyrinato]­Cu, and [tetrakis­(4-carboxytetraphenyl)­porphyrinato]­Cu (TCBPP-Cu, TCTPP-Cu, and TCTTPP-Cu, respectively) (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was used to unambiguously identify the structures of these MOFs with the isolated π-interaction sites. Spectroscopic studies including solid-state NMR (ssNMR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and UV–vis spectrum revealed quantitative adsorption of large organic guest molecules into the pores of these MOFs, where each porphyrin π-interaction site was capable of capturing two organic molecules from aqueous media, corresponding to six molecules per unit cell (B).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

π-Interaction, widely existent in biosystems, plays a critical role in their reversible and repetitive operations in aqueous media. Such dynamics are highly desirable in artificial materials for applications including catalysis, molecular separation, sensing, and drug delivery. One critical challenge for the introduction of π-interaction sites into solid-state materials is the interference between these sites at adjacent positions, which limits the access of guest molecules. Theoretically, this should be achievable in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), where the organic linkers are well separated. Extensive efforts were made toward this direction; however, repetitive and reversible dynamics are yet to be demonstrated owing to either the limited pore space in MOFs or the lack of chemical stability in water. Here, we report the repetitive and reversible dynamics in MOFs by fixing π-interaction sites in the backbone instead of protruding into the pores, and thus sufficient pore space was generated for the access of large organic guests, obviating intermolecular interference (B). Specifically, a series of mesoporous MOFs, MOF-526, -527, and -528, with progressively increased pore sizes from 1.9 to 3.7 nm, were constructed by three organic linkers with copper coordinating porphyrin units in the center as the π-interaction sites: [tetrakis(4-carboxybiphenyl)porphyrinato]Cu, [tetrakis(4-carboxytriphenyl)porphyrinato]Cu, and [tetrakis(4-carboxytetraphenyl)porphyrinato]Cu (TCBPP-Cu, TCTPP-Cu, and TCTTPP-Cu, respectively) (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was used to unambiguously identify the structures of these MOFs with the isolated π-interaction sites. Spectroscopic studies including solid-state NMR (ssNMR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and UV-vis spectrum revealed quantitative adsorption of large organic guest molecules into the pores of these MOFs, where each porphyrin π-interaction site was capable of capturing two organic molecules from aqueous media, corresponding to six molecules per unit cell (B).

elements.content: Introduction of dynamic and reversible operations in robust metal–organic frameworks by incorporating specific π-interaction sites into the structure’s backbone. (A) Features of materials linked by various bonding types. Strong bonding led to the robustness in solid-state materials, such as porous crystals, whereas relatively weak interactions allow for dynamics and reversibility in molecules. (B) Illustration of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone capable of repeated dynamic functions by specific and reversible interaction with polycyclic guest molecules.
elements.clean_text: 1  Introduction of dynamic and reversible operations in robust metal-organic frameworks by incorporating specific π-interaction sites into the structure's backbone. (A) Features of materials linked by various bonding types. Strong bonding led to the robustness in solid-state materials, such as porous crystals, whereas relatively weak interactions allow for dynamics and reversibility in molecules. (B) Illustration of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone capable of repeated dynamic functions by specific and reversible interaction with polycyclic guest molecules.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of a series of mesoporous MOFs with isolated π-interaction sites. (A) Crystal structures of MOFs with progressively expended pore sizes and pore apertures displayed along with the porphyrin organic linkers for their synthesis. (B) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and optical images of MOF-526, -527, and -528.
elements.clean_text: 2  Design and synthesis of a series of mesoporous MOFs with isolated π-interaction sites. (A) Crystal structures of MOFs with progressively expended pore sizes and pore apertures displayed along with the porphyrin organic linkers for their synthesis. (B) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and optical images of MOF-526, -527, and -528.

elements.content: Unlike previous studies, where organic macrocycles were usually used for the recognition of guest molecules within their cavity, here, the π-interaction site was a planar porphyrin unit introduced in a series of extended organic linkers. The largest dimension of the organic linker can reach 45 Å. Thus, both sides of the planar porphyrin unit were accessible for organic guest molecules through specific π-interaction. Although a large variety of porphyrin-based MOFs were synthesized and tested for applications such as catalysis, separation, and recognition, it is the first time to reveal the quantitative ratio with large organic guests and utilize specific π-interaction for water treatment. This unique feature of MOFs combined with their excellent chemical stability makes them excel in both kinetics and recyclability for the removal of large organic molecules from water, which rivals the state-of-the-art carbon and polymers.
elements.clean_text: Unlike previous studies, where organic macrocycles were usually used for the recognition of guest molecules within their cavity, here, the π-interaction site was a planar porphyrin unit introduced in a series of extended organic linkers. The largest dimension of the organic linker can reach 45 Å. Thus, both sides of the planar porphyrin unit were accessible for organic guest molecules through specific π-interaction. Although a large variety of porphyrin-based MOFs were synthesized and tested for applications such as catalysis, separation, and recognition, it is the first time to reveal the quantitative ratio with large organic guests and utilize specific π-interaction for water treatment. This unique feature of MOFs combined with their excellent chemical stability makes them excel in both kinetics and recyclability for the removal of large organic molecules from water, which rivals the state-of-the-art carbon and polymers.

elements.content: Crystals of MOF-526, -527, -528, and -536 were synthesized by mixing different linkers with ZrCl4 in dimethylformaldehyde (DMF) at 120–130 °C in an isothermal oven. The as-synthesized MOF crystals were sequentially treated with fresh DMF and acetone and followed with supercritical CO2 treatments to prepare activated samples. The detailed synthesis and activation process can be found in Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Crystals of MOF-526, -527, -528, and -536 were synthesized by mixing different linkers with ZrCl4 in dimethylformaldehyde (DMF) at 120-130 °C in an isothermal oven. The as-synthesized MOF crystals were sequentially treated with fresh DMF and acetone and followed with supercritical CO2 treatments to prepare activated samples. The detailed synthesis and activation process can be found in Supporting Information.

elements.content: The phase purity of each sample was examined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and polarizing optical microscopy. The PXRD patterns were collected on a Rigaku Smartlab 9 kW diffractometer operated at 45 kV, 200 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å), in parallel-beam geometry. All of the single-crystal X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker APEXII kappa diffractometer equipped with a charge-coupled device detector using Cu Kα radiation with λ = 1.54178 Å at 45 kV/30 mA. The incident X-ray beam was focused and monochromated using Bruker Excalibur Gobel mirror optics. N2 adsorption experiments were carried out on a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ automatic volumetric instrument. Ultrahigh-purity-grade N2 and He gases were used in all adsorption measurements.
elements.clean_text: The phase purity of each sample was examined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and polarizing optical microscopy. The PXRD patterns were collected on a Rigaku Smartlab 9 kW diffractometer operated at 45 kV, 200 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å), in parallel-beam geometry. All of the single-crystal X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker APEXII kappa diffractometer equipped with a charge-coupled device detector using Cu Kα radiation with λ = 1.54178 Å at 45 kV/30 mA. The incident X-ray beam was focused and monochromated using Bruker Excalibur Gobel mirror optics. N2 adsorption experiments were carried out on a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ automatic volumetric instrument. Ultrahigh-purity-grade N2 and He gases were used in all adsorption measurements.

elements.content: The parent structure and the smallest member of this isoreticular MOF series is MOF-525, a chemically stable microporous MOF constructed by linking 12-connected zirconium oxide clusters [Zr6(OH)4O4(CO2)12] with a porphyrin linker with a square planar shape [tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin, abbreviated as H2-TCPP]. The strong bonding between Zr4+, a hard Lewis acid, and the oxygen in carboxylate of the linker guaranteed the robustness and chemical stability of the entire family of these MOFs. The larger members of this series were created by insertion of benzene or phenylene units into the TCPP linker between the carboxylate and porphyrin π-interaction site (). This not only favors the purification during the synthetic process of the linker but also provides the reversibility required in the growth of the corresponding MOF crystals. The underlying cubic ftw topology was inherited by all of the extended MOF members in this series, and the fixation of the porphyrin unit at the center of each face in the cubic lattice led to excellent isolation of these π-interaction sites, leading to dynamic and reversible interaction with guest molecules. To optimize the performance of the π-interaction sites, the pore sizes of these MOFs were extended systematically as the size of the linker increased from 2.0 to 4.5 nm (TCPP, TCBPP, TCTPP, TCTTPP). Each of the linker was prepared in the gram scale (Section S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The parent structure and the smallest member of this isoreticular MOF series is MOF-525, a chemically stable microporous MOF constructed by linking 12-connected zirconium oxide clusters [Zr6(OH)4O4(CO2)12] with a porphyrin linker with a square planar shape [tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin, abbreviated as H2-TCPP]. The strong bonding between Zr4+, a hard Lewis acid, and the oxygen in carboxylate of the linker guaranteed the robustness and chemical stability of the entire family of these MOFs. The larger members of this series were created by insertion of benzene or phenylene units into the TCPP linker between the carboxylate and porphyrin π-interaction site (). This not only favors the purification during the synthetic process of the linker but also provides the reversibility required in the growth of the corresponding MOF crystals. The underlying cubic ftw topology was inherited by all of the extended MOF members in this series, and the fixation of the porphyrin unit at the center of each face in the cubic lattice led to excellent isolation of these π-interaction sites, leading to dynamic and reversible interaction with guest molecules. To optimize the performance of the π-interaction sites, the pore sizes of these MOFs were extended systematically as the size of the linker increased from 2.0 to 4.5 nm (TCPP, TCBPP, TCTPP, TCTTPP). Each of the linker was prepared in the gram scale (Section S2).

elements.content: The typical synthesis of these MOFs was achieved by solvothermal reaction of the organic linkers with ZrCl4 in DMF between 120 and 130 °C in the oven. Dark red cubic crystals with the size suitable for single-crystal X-ray analyses were yielded after 24–80 h (). The materials are highly crystalline, as demonstrated by the sharp peaks in their powder X-ray diffraction patterns ( and Section S3). Single-crystal X-ray analysis identified the atomic structures of all three MOFs, and revealed an identical space group of Pm3̅m for MOF-526, -527, and -528 and ftw topology (Section S4). The pore size of the parent MOF-525 was 19.4 Å. As the size of the organic linker increases, the pore sizes of MOF-526, -527, and -528 were expanded progressively to 25.5, 31.4, and 37.6 Å, respectively, with an arithmetic progression of ∼6 Å per phenylene unit. The pore opening also increased systematically from 12 × 20 to 21 × 33 Å for MOF-526, -527, and -528, respectively (Figure S2). The phase purity of each MOF was confirmed by the singular nature of the cubic crystal morphology as observed in the polarizing microscope images, and their PXRD patterns that match the simulated ones (). MOFs in the ftw topology with π-interaction sites have been reported; however, these π-interaction sites have not been ultilized for specific interaction with large π-conjugated molecules. We also found that a 2-fold interpenetrated structure could be formed when TCBPP-Fe was used, generating MOF-536 (). Although it is topologically allowed, all structures in the ftw topology were non-interpenetrated. It is worth noting that the organic linkers in the crystal structure of MOF-536 were clearly distorted because of interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: The typical synthesis of these MOFs was achieved by solvothermal reaction of the organic linkers with ZrCl4 in DMF between 120 and 130 °C in the oven. Dark red cubic crystals with the size suitable for single-crystal X-ray analyses were yielded after 24-80 h (). The materials are highly crystalline, as demonstrated by the sharp peaks in their powder X-ray diffraction patterns ( and Section S3). Single-crystal X-ray analysis identified the atomic structures of all three MOFs, and revealed an identical space group of Pm3̅m for MOF-526, -527, and -528 and ftw topology (Section S4). The pore size of the parent MOF-525 was 19.4 Å. As the size of the organic linker increases, the pore sizes of MOF-526, -527, and -528 were expanded progressively to 25.5, 31.4, and 37.6 Å, respectively, with an arithmetic progression of ~6 Å per phenylene unit. The pore opening also increased systematically from 12 × 20 to 21 × 33 Å for MOF-526, -527, and -528, respectively (Figure S2). The phase purity of each MOF was confirmed by the singular nature of the cubic crystal morphology as observed in the polarizing microscope images, and their PXRD patterns that match the simulated ones (). MOFs in the ftw topology with π-interaction sites have been reported; however, these π-interaction sites have not been ultilized for specific interaction with large π-conjugated molecules. We also found that a 2-fold interpenetrated structure could be formed when TCBPP-Fe was used, generating MOF-536 (). Although it is topologically allowed, all structures in the ftw topology were non-interpenetrated. It is worth noting that the organic linkers in the crystal structure of MOF-536 were clearly distorted because of interpenetration.

elements.content: All four members in this MOF series, MOF-526, -527, -528, and -536, exhibit permanent porosity as a result of excellent isolation of the porphyrin π-interaction sites in their crystal structures. This allows for the full access of guest molecules into their pores. The porosity of these MOFs was studied by N2 gas adsorption measurements at 77 K (). Prior to the gas adsorption tests, the solvent molecules were removed from the pores of these MOFs. MOF-526, -527, and -528 exhibited type IV isotherms, with pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.17, 0.26, and 0.20, respectively, typical for mesoporous materials. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas were 4260, 2000, and 3550 m2/g, respectively (Section S6). The isoreticular MOFs with nonmetalated porphyrin units exhibit higher surface areas: 4620 m2/g for MOF-526-H2 and 4290 m2/g for MOF-528-H2. The pore size distribution of MOF-525, -526, and -527 calculated from the isotherms increased progressively, in good accordance with their crystal structures. The pore size of MOF-528 was lower than the theoretical value, which can be attributed to the dynamics of the linkers. This, however, did not affect the performance of MOF-528 in water because of the unaltered crystallinity reflected in sharp peaks in the PXRD pattern. The N2 adsorption isotherm for MOF-536 was type I, owing to the micropore nature of the interpenetrated structure. H4-type hysteresis in the desorption branch revealed the slit nature of the space between two interpenetrated frameworks. The pore size of MOF-536 was also smaller than that of MOF-526, and the surface area of MOF-536 was 2010 m2/g. All these MOFs exhibited excellent thermal stability as confirmed by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), where no obvious weight loss was observed until 400 °C in their TGA curves. The chemical stability of these MOFs was assessed by immersion in aqueous solutions with various pH values (pH = 2–11), where the PXRD patterns of all these MOFs remained unaltered after 36 h.

This allows for the full access of guest molecules into their pores. The porosity of these MOFs was studied by N2 gas adsorption measurements at 77 K (). Prior to the gas adsorption tests, the solvent molecules were removed from the pores of these MOFs. MOF-526, -527, and -528 exhibited type IV isotherms, with pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.17, 0.26, and 0.20, respectively, typical for mesoporous materials. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas were 4260, 2000, and 3550 m2/g, respectively (Section S6). elements.content: The permanent porosity, large pore opening, and excellent chemical stability of MOFs in this study make them ideally suited for the demonstration of reversible and repetitive dynamics in water. Here, we used a series of large organic guest molecules with different functional groups for the investigation of reversible π-interactions with MOFs by inclusion and release tests. MOFs and MOF-based composites have been explored for the interaction with large organic molecules; however, this was usually carried out in nonaqueous media because of their limited chemical stability and/or microporosity. In this study, the inclusion and release test of large organic molecules in MOFs was performed in water, where the chemical stability of these mesoporous MOFs guaranteed repetitive operation. The performances of MOF-526, -527, and -528 were tested by immersing them in the water solution of various organic molecules (rhodamine B, butyl rhodamine B, methylene blue, malachite green, methyl green, acid red 88, and lissamine rhodamine B, abbreviated as RhB, BRB, MB, MalG, MG, AR88, and LRhB, respectively). The parent MOF-525 was also used as the control. The concentration of these large organic molecules was monitored quantitatively by the intensity of its fingerprint peaks in the UV–vis spectra (Section S7). The adsorption kinetics and the uptake of each MOF were derived from the corresponding decay curves of these molecules (A–D). The results showed that the size of the pore opening was critical for inclusion kinetics of these MOFs. When the pore opening was smaller than the size of the organic molecules in the case of MOF-525, slow adsorption of RhB was observed, and the decrease in concentration was likely to be attributed to the adsorption at the surface of MOF crystals. On the other hand, the fastest adsorption kinetics was not observed in MOFs with the largest pore opening, but instead in MOF-526 with relatively small mesopores in this series. The reason for this was that although the pore opening was bigger in MOF-527 and -528, the volumetric density of π-interaction sites in the crystal decreased as the size of the crystal unit cell increased. Nevertheless, because of the presence of isolated π-interaction sites in their backbone, all three mesoporous MOFs were capable of achieving complete inclusion of RhB molecules in water within 400 min (B). All seven large aromatic organic molecules were rapidly and completely included in MOF-526 because of their appropriate pore opening and high active site densities (A). For the adsorption of RhB using MOF-526, an uptake of 720 mg/g was achieved at pH = 6. This is the highest uptake of RhB achieved in MOFs, demonstrating the sufficient pore spaces inside these mesorpous MOFs. A quantitative study revealed that two RhB molecules were observed per porphyrin π-interaction site in the MOF structure. As the pH value varied from 2 to 10, high RhB uptake was maintained with only a slight deviation from the 2:1 RhB to porphyrin ratio. This can be attributed to the excellent chemical stability of MOF-526 and the nature of π-interaction (C).

MOFs and MOF-based composites have been explored for the interaction with large organic molecules; however, this was usually carried out in nonaqueous media because of their limited chemical stability and/or microporosity. elements.content: Quantitative and reversible adsorption of a large variety of organic molecules by mesoporous MOFs with specific π-interaction sites, and their repetitive inclusion and release in water. (A) All six large polycyclic organic molecules with either positive or negative charge in aqueous solution were adsorbed efficiently and completely by MOF-526. C and C 0 were the incidental and initial concentrations of organic molecules in aqueous solution. (B) Comparison of the kinetics for RhB inclusion by MOFs in the same series, but with different pore sizes. (C) The uptake capacity of RhB (q RhB/MOF) at various pH values by MOF-526. (D) Adsorption kinetics of MOF-526 and MOF-526-H2 reflected in the association constant (K) of 4.54 × 105 and 2.1 × 105 L/mol (a smaller slope represents a higher K value), respectively. Their uptake capacities were 747 mg/g for MOF-526 and 727 mg/g for MOF-526-H2 at pH = 7. The Langmuir model was used for the fitting of the equilibrium uptake of RhB (Q e, mg/g) at different residual concentrations (C e, mol/L), which is consistent with the quantitative ratio between RhB and porphyrin π-interaction sites in MOFs, 2:1. (E) Comparison of the reversibility and repetitive operation of the state-of-the-art porous carbon (blue curves at the top) and MOF-526 (red curves in the bottom) for the inclusion and release of RhB at the initial concentration of 10 ppm. The kinetics of organic molecules’ inclusion remained unaltered for MOF-526 with specific π-interaction sites after 10 repeated cycles, whereas that of porous carbon decreased after the second cycle because of the lack of specific interaction.
elements.clean_text: 3  Quantitative and reversible adsorption of a large variety of organic molecules by mesoporous MOFs with specific π-interaction sites, and their repetitive inclusion and release in water. (A) All six large polycyclic organic molecules with either positive or negative charge in aqueous solution were adsorbed efficiently and completely by MOF-526. C and C 0 were the incidental and initial concentrations of organic molecules in aqueous solution. (B) Comparison of the kinetics for RhB inclusion by MOFs in the same series, but with different pore sizes. (C) The uptake capacity of RhB (q RhB/MOF) at various pH values by MOF-526. (D) Adsorption kinetics of MOF-526 and MOF-526-H2 reflected in the association constant (K) of 4.54 × 105 and 2.1 × 105 L/mol (a smaller slope represents a higher K value), respectively. Their uptake capacities were 747 mg/g for MOF-526 and 727 mg/g for MOF-526-H2 at pH = 7. The Langmuir model was used for the fitting of the equilibrium uptake of RhB (Q e, mg/g) at different residual concentrations (C e, mol/L), which is consistent with the quantitative ratio between RhB and porphyrin π-interaction sites in MOFs, 2:1. (E) Comparison of the reversibility and repetitive operation of the state-of-the-art porous carbon (blue curves at the top) and MOF-526 (red curves in the bottom) for the inclusion and release of RhB at the initial concentration of 10 ppm. The kinetics of organic molecules' inclusion remained unaltered for MOF-526 with specific π-interaction sites after 10 repeated cycles, whereas that of porous carbon decreased after the second cycle because of the lack of specific interaction.

elements.content: The adsorption kinetics and reversibility for the inclusion and release of organic guests were also tested, in addition to their quantitative uptake. Adsorption kinetics are usually represented by the association constant K, which is obtained by fitting the Langmuir model with the equilibrium uptake of organic molecules at different initial concentrations. The K values measured for MOF-526-H2 and MOF-526 were 2.10 × 105 and 4.54 × 105 L/mol, respectively (D). The latter value was unprecedented in porous materials, such as MOFs, polymers, and carbon. The recycle performance was another critical parameter to assess the dynamics, and it was evaluated by repeated inclusion–release cycles. In the case of RhB inclusion by MOF-526, adsorbed RhB molecules were completely released from the pores when washed with ethanol; at the same time, the uptake capacity of MOF-526 was regenerated and ready for the next adsorption cycle. This was repeated for at least 10 complete cycles without any decay in the uptake capacity and adsorption kinetics for MOF-526 (E). In contrast, the porous carbon used as control can only be recycled four times, and the adsorption kinetics dropped quickly after each cycle. The excellent recyclability of MOF-526 can be attributed to the specific π-interaction between the porphyrin units and organic molecules. The unaltered PXRD pattern of MOF-526 after 10 continuous cycles again confirmed its excellent chemical stability (Figure S40). The above performance assessments revealed the uniqueness and advantages of MOFs in the inclusion and release of large organic molecules, and outlined the importance of isolated π-interaction sites in this series of mesoporous MOFs. To confirm the dominant contribution of π-interaction among various possible forces between large aromatic organic molecules and MOFs, a series of control experiments were performed. In general, the other possible interactions are (a) coordination bond, (b) ionic interaction, (c) hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect, and (d) hydrogen bond. First of all, organic molecule inclusion was tested on MOF-526-H2, without any metal in the porphyrin center. This MOF exhibited complete and efficient inclusion of RhB from water within 150 min, which is similar to that of MOF-526 with copper coordinating to the porphyrin unit (Figure S37). The uptake capacities of MOF-526-H2 and MOF-526 were almost identical: 727 and 747 mg/g, respectively (D). These results indicated that coordination bond was unlikely to be the main interaction. The slight improvement in performance when metal ions were coordinated with porphyrin can be attributed to the enhanced π-conjugation of the porphyrin unit. The coordination with the zirconium oxide second building unit was ruled out by the unaltered Zr 3d5/2 peaks in the XPS spectra of RhB-adsorbed MOF-526 in comparison with that of pure MOF (Figure S43). Second, both positively and negatively charged organic molecules were completely included by these mesoporous MOFs; thus, the ionic interaction should have little influence on the adsorption of organic molecules here (A). Third, the impact of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect was studied by using both hydrophobic and hydrophilic derivatives of RhB (lissamine rhodamine B and butyl rhodamine B). Although slight differences existed, complete and efficient inclusion of all three kinds of rhodamine B ruled out the major contribution of a hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect (A). Last but not the least, organic molecule inclusion experiments were conducted at 95 °C, when the hydrogen bond was broken. RhB molecules were completely included with similar kinetics by MOF-526, indicating that hydrogen bond was not crucial.
elements.clean_text: The adsorption kinetics and reversibility for the inclusion and release of organic guests were also tested, in addition to their quantitative uptake. Adsorption kinetics are usually represented by the association constant K, which is obtained by fitting the Langmuir model with the equilibrium uptake of organic molecules at different initial concentrations. The K values measured for MOF-526-H2 and MOF-526 were 2.10 × 105 and 4.54 × 105 L/mol, respectively (D). The latter value was unprecedented in porous materials, such as MOFs, polymers, and carbon. The recycle performance was another critical parameter to assess the dynamics, and it was evaluated by repeated inclusion-release cycles. In the case of RhB inclusion by MOF-526, adsorbed RhB molecules were completely released from the pores when washed with ethanol; at the same time, the uptake capacity of MOF-526 was regenerated and ready for the next adsorption cycle. This was repeated for at least 10 complete cycles without any decay in the uptake capacity and adsorption kinetics for MOF-526 (E). In contrast, the porous carbon used as control can only be recycled four times, and the adsorption kinetics dropped quickly after each cycle. The excellent recyclability of MOF-526 can be attributed to the specific π-interaction between the porphyrin units and organic molecules. The unaltered PXRD pattern of MOF-526 after 10 continuous cycles again confirmed its excellent chemical stability (Figure S40). The above performance assessments revealed the uniqueness and advantages of MOFs in the inclusion and release of large organic molecules, and outlined the importance of isolated π-interaction sites in this series of mesoporous MOFs. To confirm the dominant contribution of π-interaction among various possible forces between large aromatic organic molecules and MOFs, a series of control experiments were performed. In general, the other possible interactions are (a) coordination bond, (b) ionic interaction, (c) hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect, and (d) hydrogen bond. First of all, organic molecule inclusion was tested on MOF-526-H2, without any metal in the porphyrin center. This MOF exhibited complete and efficient inclusion of RhB from water within 150 min, which is similar to that of MOF-526 with copper coordinating to the porphyrin unit (Figure S37). The uptake capacities of MOF-526-H2 and MOF-526 were almost identical: 727 and 747 mg/g, respectively (D). These results indicated that coordination bond was unlikely to be the main interaction. The slight improvement in performance when metal ions were coordinated with porphyrin can be attributed to the enhanced π-conjugation of the porphyrin unit. The coordination with the zirconium oxide second building unit was ruled out by the unaltered Zr 3d5/2 peaks in the XPS spectra of RhB-adsorbed MOF-526 in comparison with that of pure MOF (Figure S43). Second, both positively and negatively charged organic molecules were completely included by these mesoporous MOFs; thus, the ionic interaction should have little influence on the adsorption of organic molecules here (A). Third, the impact of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect was studied by using both hydrophobic and hydrophilic derivatives of RhB (lissamine rhodamine B and butyl rhodamine B). Although slight differences existed, complete and efficient inclusion of all three kinds of rhodamine B ruled out the major contribution of a hydrophobic/hydrophilic effect (A). Last but not the least, organic molecule inclusion experiments were conducted at 95 °C, when the hydrogen bond was broken. RhB molecules were completely included with similar kinetics by MOF-526, indicating that hydrogen bond was not crucial.

elements.content: Spectroscopic studies, such as UV–vis and solid-state NMR spectroscopy, were used to gain insight into the π-interaction. UV–vis spectra were measured on the aqueous solution of porphyrin containing TCBPP linkers (6 mg/L) mixed with RhB at different concentrations. Blue shift in the Soret band of the porphyrin unit was observed for all mixtures above in comparison with the pure TCBPP linker, demonstrating the change in π–π* excitation of the porphyrin units (Figures S41 and S42). This was also a clear evidence for the π-interaction between RhB and MOF linkers. Similar phenomena were observed in experiments using other large aromatic organic molecules including BRB, MG, MalG, and LRhB, each of which exhibited a different shift in the Soret band of the linker. Solid-state NMR experiments were also performed to investigate the interaction between large organic molecules and MOF, using MOF-526-H2 and RhB as illustration, where the porphyrin units in MOF-526-H2 were labeled by 15N to achieve an enhanced signal-to-noise ratio. In 13C cross-polarization/magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) NMR experiments, shifts were observed in the fingerprint peaks of both RhB molecules (positions a, b, and c) and the conjugated porphyrin rings (positions f, g, and their equivalent positions) in the MOF backbone, revealing interaction between them (E). Similarly, in 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra, shifts in nitrogen signal were observed when MOF-526-H2 contacted RhB with and without the involvement of water molecules (F). Although a bigger shift was observed on the nonprotonated N atom (labeled as i), as a result of porphyrin units interacting with water to form a hydrogen bond, the nature of π-interaction between RhB and MOF was not altered in the presence of water. The relatively weaker π-interaction, in comparison with hydrogen bond, gave rise to the excellent reversibility for the inclusion and release of large organic molecules using MOFs, illustrating the advantage of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone ().
elements.clean_text: Spectroscopic studies, such as UV-vis and solid-state NMR spectroscopy, were used to gain insight into the π-interaction. UV-vis spectra were measured on the aqueous solution of porphyrin containing TCBPP linkers (6 mg/L) mixed with RhB at different concentrations. Blue shift in the Soret band of the porphyrin unit was observed for all mixtures above in comparison with the pure TCBPP linker, demonstrating the change in π-π* excitation of the porphyrin units (Figures S41 and S42). This was also a clear evidence for the π-interaction between RhB and MOF linkers. Similar phenomena were observed in experiments using other large aromatic organic molecules including BRB, MG, MalG, and LRhB, each of which exhibited a different shift in the Soret band of the linker. Solid-state NMR experiments were also performed to investigate the interaction between large organic molecules and MOF, using MOF-526-H2 and RhB as illustration, where the porphyrin units in MOF-526-H2 were labeled by 15N to achieve an enhanced signal-to-noise ratio. In 13C cross-polarization/magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) NMR experiments, shifts were observed in the fingerprint peaks of both RhB molecules (positions a, b, and c) and the conjugated porphyrin rings (positions f, g, and their equivalent positions) in the MOF backbone, revealing interaction between them (E). Similarly, in 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra, shifts in nitrogen signal were observed when MOF-526-H2 contacted RhB with and without the involvement of water molecules (F). Although a bigger shift was observed on the nonprotonated N atom (labeled as i), as a result of porphyrin units interacting with water to form a hydrogen bond, the nature of π-interaction between RhB and MOF was not altered in the presence of water. The relatively weaker π-interaction, in comparison with hydrogen bond, gave rise to the excellent reversibility for the inclusion and release of large organic molecules using MOFs, illustrating the advantage of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone ().

elements.content: Investigation of the specific π-interaction between the porphyrin unit in the MOF backbone and RhB molecules. (A) Illustration of RhB configuration with respect to the crystal structure of MOF-526-H2, based on the distances measured by ssNMR at various positions. (B) Chemical structures of the TCBPP linker and RhB molecules with the labels of 13C and 15N atoms. (C, D) Distances between specific 13C (a/b at 12 ppm and c at 130 ppm) and 15N atoms given by their corresponding experimental 13C­{15N} rotational-echo double-resonance (REDOR) data (triangles) and simulated decay curves by numerical simulations. (E) 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra of MOF-526-H2 and RhB-adsorbed MOF-526-H2 samples. Chemical shift in the 15N signals at both i and j positions confirmed the formation of π-interaction between the porphyrin unit in the MOF backbone and RhB molecules with and without the involvement of water. (F) 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra of MOF-526-H2 and RhB-loaded MOF-526-H2 samples. Chemical shift in the 13C signals at a, b, and c positions in RhB and f and g positions in MOF-526-H2 revealed the interactions between them.
elements.clean_text: 4  Investigation of the specific π-interaction between the porphyrin unit in the MOF backbone and RhB molecules. (A) Illustration of RhB configuration with respect to the crystal structure of MOF-526-H2, based on the distances measured by ssNMR at various positions. (B) Chemical structures of the TCBPP linker and RhB molecules with the labels of 13C and 15N atoms. (C, D) Distances between specific 13C (a/b at 12 ppm and c at 130 ppm) and 15N atoms given by their corresponding experimental 13C{15N} rotational-echo double-resonance (REDOR) data (triangles) and simulated decay curves by numerical simulations. (E) 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra of MOF-526-H2 and RhB-adsorbed MOF-526-H2 samples. Chemical shift in the 15N signals at both i and j positions confirmed the formation of π-interaction between the porphyrin unit in the MOF backbone and RhB molecules with and without the involvement of water. (F) 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra of MOF-526-H2 and RhB-loaded MOF-526-H2 samples. Chemical shift in the 13C signals at a, b, and c positions in RhB and f and g positions in MOF-526-H2 revealed the interactions between them.

elements.content: Last but not the least, the distance between RhB molecules and the porphyrin π-interaction site in the MOF backbone was measured at various positions by rotational-echo double-resonance (REDOR) solid-state NMR experiments. The dipolar coupling between 15N atoms in the porphyrin units and 13C spins of the RhB molecules was measured by simulating the REDOR dephasing curves. In the 13C­{15N} REDOR experiment, 13C signals were collected at a given recoupling time with and without 15N dipolar modulation, corresponding to S and S0, respectively (Figure S44). The experimental S/S 0 values were compared against the simulated decay curves of 13C–15N dipole coupling at different distances between 13C–15N pairs (r), where the correlation between 13C–15N dipole coupling and 1/r 3 existed. In this way, the distance between the corresponding 13C and 15N atoms was obtained. To validate the accuracy of this method, the distances between the 15N atoms and the 13C atoms within the TCBPP linker were analyzed as internal standards, and also to obtain the numerical simulation parameters (Figures S46 and S47). The distance from the 15N atoms in the TCBPP linker to the 13C atoms in RhB molecules at position c peak with a chemical shift of 130 ppm was 3.24 Å, whereas that from 15N atoms to 13C atoms at position a/b with a chemical shift of 12 ppm was 3.37 Å (A,C,D); both were in the typical range of π-interactions. Again, this accurate distance measurement pinned the relative position of RhB to the porphyrin π-interaction sites in the backbone of MOF-526-H2. This was achieved in a face-to-face configuration, at both sides of the linkers, which explains the 2:1 ratio between the RhB molecules and TCBPP linkers.
elements.clean_text: Last but not the least, the distance between RhB molecules and the porphyrin π-interaction site in the MOF backbone was measured at various positions by rotational-echo double-resonance (REDOR) solid-state NMR experiments. The dipolar coupling between 15N atoms in the porphyrin units and 13C spins of the RhB molecules was measured by simulating the REDOR dephasing curves. In the 13C{15N} REDOR experiment, 13C signals were collected at a given recoupling time with and without 15N dipolar modulation, corresponding to S and S0, respectively (Figure S44). The experimental S/S 0 values were compared against the simulated decay curves of 13C-15N dipole coupling at different distances between 13C-15N pairs (r), where the correlation between 13C-15N dipole coupling and 1/r 3 existed. In this way, the distance between the corresponding 13C and 15N atoms was obtained. To validate the accuracy of this method, the distances between the 15N atoms and the 13C atoms within the TCBPP linker were analyzed as internal standards, and also to obtain the numerical simulation parameters (Figures S46 and S47). The distance from the 15N atoms in the TCBPP linker to the 13C atoms in RhB molecules at position c peak with a chemical shift of 130 ppm was 3.24 Å, whereas that from 15N atoms to 13C atoms at position a/b with a chemical shift of 12 ppm was 3.37 Å (A,C,D); both were in the typical range of π-interactions. Again, this accurate distance measurement pinned the relative position of RhB to the porphyrin π-interaction sites in the backbone of MOF-526-H2. This was achieved in a face-to-face configuration, at both sides of the linkers, which explains the 2:1 ratio between the RhB molecules and TCBPP linkers.

elements.content: We showed that isolated π-interaction sites can be created at the backbone of mesoporous MOFs without intermolecular interference. These π-interaction sites were capable of repetitive and reversible dynamics in interacting with large polycyclic hydrocarbons, where each site attracted two guest molecules in a quantitative manner. These mesoporous MOFs were well suited for the inclusion and release of large organic molecules with unprecedented kinetics. The isolation of specific π-interaction sites and mesoporosity were the key elements for the quantitative and reversible nature of MOFs in their interaction with guest molecules. This represents a new way to excise robust dynamics in solid-state materials.
elements.clean_text: We showed that isolated π-interaction sites can be created at the backbone of mesoporous MOFs without intermolecular interference. These π-interaction sites were capable of repetitive and reversible dynamics in interacting with large polycyclic hydrocarbons, where each site attracted two guest molecules in a quantitative manner. These mesoporous MOFs were well suited for the inclusion and release of large organic molecules with unprecedented kinetics. The isolation of specific π-interaction sites and mesoporosity were the key elements for the quantitative and reversible nature of MOFs in their interaction with guest molecules. This represents a new way to excise robust dynamics in solid-state materials.

cln_elements.content: All four members in this MOF series, MOF-526, -527, -528, and -536, exhibit permanent porosity as a result of excellent isolation of the porphyrin π-interaction sites in their crystal structures. This allows for the full access of guest molecules into their pores. The porosity of these MOFs was studied by N2 gas adsorption measurements at 77 K (). Prior to the gas adsorption tests, the solvent molecules were removed from the pores of these MOFs. MOF-526, -527, and -528 exhibited type IV isotherms, with pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.17, 0.26, and 0.20, respectively, typical for mesoporous materials. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas were 4260, 2000, and 3550 m2/g, respectively (Section S6). The isoreticular MOFs with nonmetalated porphyrin units exhibit higher surface areas: 4620 m2/g for MOF-526-H2 and 4290 m2/g for MOF-528-H2. The pore size distribution of MOF-525, -526, and -527 calculated from the isotherms increased progressively, in good accordance with their crystal structures. The pore size of MOF-528 was lower than the theoretical value, which can be attributed to the dynamics of the linkers. This, however, did not affect the performance of MOF-528 in water because of the unaltered crystallinity reflected in sharp peaks in the PXRD pattern. The N2 adsorption isotherm for MOF-536 was type I, owing to the micropore nature of the interpenetrated structure. H4-type hysteresis in the desorption branch revealed the slit nature of the space between two interpenetrated frameworks. The pore size of MOF-536 was also smaller than that of MOF-526, and the surface area of MOF-536 was 2010 m2/g. All these MOFs exhibited excellent thermal stability as confirmed by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), where no obvious weight loss was observed until 400 °C in their TGA curves. The chemical stability of these MOFs was assessed by immersion in aqueous solutions with various pH values (pH = 2–11), where the PXRD patterns of all these MOFs remained unaltered after 36 h.

This allows for the full access of guest molecules into their pores. The porosity of these MOFs was studied by N2 gas adsorption measurements at 77 K (). MOF-526, -527, and -528 exhibited type IV isotherms, with pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.17, 0.26, and 0.20, respectively, typical for mesoporous materials. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas were 4260, 2000, and 3550 m2/g, respectively (Section S6). The isoreticular MOFs with nonmetalated porphyrin units exhibit higher surface areas: 4620 m2/g for MOF-526-H2 and 4290 m2/g for MOF-528-H2. The pore size distribution of MOF-525, -526, and -527 calculated from the isotherms increased progressively, in good accordance with their crystal structures. The pore size of MOF-536 was also smaller than that of MOF-526, and the surface area of MOF-536 was 2010 m2/g. gas adsorption.condition: type IV isotherms, pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.17
type IV isotherms, pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.26
type IV isotherms, pore-filling steps at P/P 0 = 0.20
type I isotherm, H4-type hysteresis in the desorption branch

cln_elements.content: Introduction of dynamic and reversible operations in robust metal–organic frameworks by incorporating specific π-interaction sites into the structure’s backbone. (A) Features of materials linked by various bonding types. Strong bonding led to the robustness in solid-state materials, such as porous crystals, whereas relatively weak interactions allow for dynamics and reversibility in molecules. (B) Illustration of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone capable of repeated dynamic functions by specific and reversible interaction with polycyclic guest molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Introduction of dynamic and reversible operations in robust metal-organic frameworks by incorporating specific π-interaction sites into the structure's backbone. (A) Features of materials linked by various bonding types. Strong bonding led to the robustness in solid-state materials, such as porous crystals, whereas relatively weak interactions allow for dynamics and reversibility in molecules. (B) Illustration of isolated π-interaction sites in the MOF backbone capable of repeated dynamic functions by specific and reversible interaction with polycyclic guest molecules.

cln_elements.content: Design and synthesis of a series of mesoporous MOFs with isolated π-interaction sites. (A) Crystal structures of MOFs with progressively expended pore sizes and pore apertures displayed along with the porphyrin organic linkers for their synthesis. (B) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and optical images of MOF-526, -527, and -528.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Design and synthesis of a series of mesoporous MOFs with isolated π-interaction sites. (A) Crystal structures of MOFs with progressively expended pore sizes and pore apertures displayed along with the porphyrin organic linkers for their synthesis. (B) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and optical images of MOF-526, -527, and -528.

cln_elements.content: Quantitative and reversible adsorption of a large variety of organic molecules by mesoporous MOFs with specific π-interaction sites, and their repetitive inclusion and release in water. (A) All six large polycyclic organic molecules with either positive or negative charge in aqueous solution were adsorbed efficiently and completely by MOF-526. C and C 0 were the incidental and initial concentrations of organic molecules in aqueous solution. (B) Comparison of the kinetics for RhB inclusion by MOFs in the same series, but with different pore sizes. (C) The uptake capacity of RhB (q RhB/MOF) at various pH values by MOF-526. (D) Adsorption kinetics of MOF-526 and MOF-526-H2 reflected in the association constant (K) of 4.54 × 105 and 2.1 × 105 L/mol (a smaller slope represents a higher K value), respectively. Their uptake capacities were 747 mg/g for MOF-526 and 727 mg/g for MOF-526-H2 at pH = 7. The Langmuir model was used for the fitting of the equilibrium uptake of RhB (Q e, mg/g) at different residual concentrations (C e, mol/L), which is consistent with the quantitative ratio between RhB and porphyrin π-interaction sites in MOFs, 2:1. (E) Comparison of the reversibility and repetitive operation of the state-of-the-art porous carbon (blue curves at the top) and MOF-526 (red curves in the bottom) for the inclusion and release of RhB at the initial concentration of 10 ppm. The kinetics of organic molecules’ inclusion remained unaltered for MOF-526 with specific π-interaction sites after 10 repeated cycles, whereas that of porous carbon decreased after the second cycle because of the lack of specific interaction.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Quantitative and reversible adsorption of a large variety of organic molecules by mesoporous MOFs with specific π-interaction sites, and their repetitive inclusion and release in water. (A) All six large polycyclic organic molecules with either positive or negative charge in aqueous solution were adsorbed efficiently and completely by MOF-526. C and C 0 were the incidental and initial concentrations of organic molecules in aqueous solution. (B) Comparison of the kinetics for RhB inclusion by MOFs in the same series, but with different pore sizes. (C) The uptake capacity of RhB (q RhB/MOF) at various pH values by MOF-526. (D) Adsorption kinetics of MOF-526 and MOF-526-H2 reflected in the association constant (K) of 4.54 × 105 and 2.1 × 105 L/mol (a smaller slope represents a higher K value), respectively. Their uptake capacities were 747 mg/g for MOF-526 and 727 mg/g for MOF-526-H2 at pH = 7. The Langmuir model was used for the fitting of the equilibrium uptake of RhB (Q e, mg/g) at different residual concentrations (C e, mol/L), which is consistent with the quantitative ratio between RhB and porphyrin π-interaction sites in MOFs, 2:1. (E) Comparison of the reversibility and repetitive operation of the state-of-the-art porous carbon (blue curves at the top) and MOF-526 (red curves in the bottom) for the inclusion and release of RhB at the initial concentration of 10 ppm. The kinetics of organic molecules' inclusion remained unaltered for MOF-526 with specific π-interaction sites after 10 repeated cycles, whereas that of porous carbon decreased after the second cycle because of the lack of specific interaction.

metadata.title:
Isolated
π‑Interaction Sites in Mesoporous
MOF Backbone for Repetitive and Reversible Dynamics in Water
